JS3pipzDonyF3T9112FS3w.text: My friend loves Nakama so when she came to visit me, we decided to get dinner here. We ordered sushi and appetizer to share. The sushi was decent but overall, not very memorable. If you want authentic sushi, I highly recommend Chaya in Squirrel Hill!

209j0DcnELfJZj5U2cEGvw.text: Literally my favorite Japanese place ever.  I love sushi, but my boyfriend isn't a huge fan, so I got the Boston roll and he got the steak tips. AMAZING.  We no longer live in the area, but we always visit it when we're in town.

WfBXZ0Kgj8qi4f88orpiZA.text: Love this place - good food decent price! Great times!

_-MRmlHl8psqQX42nZTZJw.text: May be a decent place to eat hibachi...BUT NOT sushi or sashimi!!!!  I have tried Nakama's 3 times to be fair.  Nakama can not live up to it's name as a "Sushi Bar".  Don't waste your time, money or taste buds....

ArfDjxxBpmvLbVZYjqAMoQ.text: My wife and I have been visited this establishment during the day, and on a Saturday night.  I am not expect on Japanese food, but I like what I had.  I am out of Atlanta, so the prices are great.  Nice place to start a Saturday night out, and nice for a business meal.

pgTc-wumqHGTZg13kZJHmQ.text: I really thought that Nakama was a great place.   We went there for Valentines day. They had great specials and they also provided a complimentary rose with your reservation. It really seemed like they cared about the little details.   The restaurant was very clean and decorated nicely. It has a large bar and sushi in the front. I really liked the open design and tall ceilings because it gave the feeling of having a lot of space.   The wait staff was very friendly and very prompt with service and bringing drinks.   I wouldn't say that it was any more busy/noicey then any other hibachi type restaurant. These always draw crowds and tend to be noisy. The pricing is also on par with any other restaurant of this type.   If I had a complaint was it did take a little long for our cook to come out.  They did serve soup and salad quickly.   I would go again and recommend it to friends.

iMCxvz5_KSeFhnqmgCBXxA.text: I went here for my boyfriend's birthday and did hibachi... and it was good! There was a LOT of food, which is probably why it's so expensive. Hibachi ranges from $20-$70 per person! Plus, they charge you for extras, like $3 extra for fried rice instead of white rice. Kind of ridiculous. The 3 of us shared a bottle of sake because it was $30/bottle so it was the cheapest option. Also, I told 4 people it was his birthday and they were supposed to bring dessert and ring a gong... but that never happened.

u7vdMO7GgzaxnnmcSXqMAw.text: Excellent spot for hibachi and sushi with friendy staff and quick service.  The Chicken Diablo dinner was delicious

RUNEzFaeBrWcHo2BA-dNdQ.text: Good fresh sushi. Get the appetizers if you can. We had the seared NY strip, which was delicious and $9.99 for quite a large portion of steak. The crab fritters were pretty good and crab-y if you are in the mood for something fried and not soaking in oil. We didn't do the hibachi, but the sushi was good. The toro jalapeno roll was pretty creative. The food is NOT overpriced for the whole package. Yes it is a bit "uppity" if you mean no one is really wearing their XXL Steelers shirt and the servers and patrons actually care what they look like. It is not a place to get a $5 roll.

1zP07kO8GxYqStxTNx3UTA.text: I've tried to like Nakama, I really have. There is a serious shortage of good sushi in the Southside.....as in there are only two places to go for it. With the renovation and new ownership of the old Sushi Two into Tokyo Bistro, Nakama has dropped to last place (or 2nd), for Sushi in south side.   Nakama has style. The interior is gorgeous. This is where it all ends and goes south though. The food is very uninspired, the waits for a table are unbelievable (and unwarranted), presentation has gone downhill over the years - and the worst part: the crowd.  For some reason, Nakama has turned into a singles scene. Please explain to me how a sushi & hibachi restaurant is now a meat-market? (fish market? hehe) Any given night of the week, you will find scantily clad fake women (could be a good thing), and old rich perverts trying to pick them up......cougars, suburbanites, screaming children....it's nuts. At peak dinner hours, you literally have to fight your way through everything. You'd think you stepped into Town Tavern by accident or something!  The other issue, and the reason why I am marking it bad for groups, is the lack of larger tables dedicated solely to sushi eaters. If you have a large group of people, you may as well pass. You can either camp out and wait for a bunch of seats to open up at the sushi bar, or sit at a hibachi grill - which is terrible for the cook if everyone in your party wants sushi.  Here are some final pros to balance this out a little bit and explain why I gave it two stars:  - Great drinks...best bloody mary I've had. - Awesome for late night food once it clears out - Good lunch specials - The aforementioned interior space  But if you really want good sushi, go to Umi in Shadyside or Pennsylvania Fish Company on Penn Ave in the strip. Nakama is not the place.

-VwSiuUGMRk03z96bP4uFA.text: As far as the sushi goes, I'll have to pass from here on out. I can never understand why this place is so packed as it is when I pass it sometimes. Oh, I know why. Because people are clueless. Yes, that's it. (And it has a good location.)

muL1fyoa3h3bTrMOS8vV2g.text: Had sushi and sashimi for lunch this week. Very generous portions and fresh. Have recently been to Tamari and Yamato and this was the best, with Tamari a close second.  Only issue was seating. We wanted a table for a meeting, but had to sit at the sushi bar because tables are limited.

8GffAREsOnBf8gLi29eHmQ.text: You would think by the crowds in this place it was the only sushi place in the whole city of Pittsburgh. I went in with good expectations of this place considering it is always crowded.....boy was I wrong!!!  First off the service at this place is horrible. This is mostly a 22-28 yr old staffed place. The hostess basically laughed at me when I said we did not have a reservation, offered us to have a drink at the bar, and then said "but you cannot stand around in this area here around the door it is getting too crowded so either the bar or maybe wait outside" ...seriously you don't tell a customer that.   We just wanted sushi anyways, so we sat at the sushi bar and ordered some rolls and sashimi. Now maybe I am spoiled from living on the west coast for so long now that I am used to Asians (usually Japanese..go figure) working and making my sushi. There were 3 white guys about 25 yrs old making my rolls for me, not to say they cannot do it as well as anyone else, but the rolls were seriously not that great.  Hell I did not even see an Asian person working at the tables either, they were mostly Mexican guys.   Sorry, I know most of the reviews are raving about how good this place is, but to me it seems pretty pricey for what you get and the food is not all that. I can only speak for the sushi...maybe the dinners at the tables are better. To sum it up this is mostly an over priced sushi bar that is a good place to hang out and have drinks with friends and maybe hit on some groups of women out for dinner.

aCjEp1RHQawwHd6IDLvi_Q.text: We've been here a few times. I think it used to be more of a scene a few years ago, but I still think the food is good. It's the same hibachi show you'll get at any of the local places. I'm vegetarian, and some of the chefs really know how to be nice to a vegetarian (cook your food first, before there's meat on the grill), but not all of them. You'll get better service if you go when they're not busy.

e_p0nA9nZN7SKL5e2rd9uQ.text: The food is good. I've  never had the sushi but Ive heard  it's very good. I only gave 3 stars bc the service is AWFUL   The manager is a pompous asshole,  Is annoyed at life And  doesn't care if you have a complaint. Acts like your disrupting his life if you have a concern.  I've eaten here and had a few good experiences but I've also has really awful experiences as well and haven't been back

klZDW6wwQJFkn0hIxioz5Q.text: I went there with people from work and it was a lot of fun.  We sat at one of the Hibachi's and ate some really good food.    The sushi was also really good and I normally am not a sushi person.  I would recommend for a fun evening.

gjGa9nLQcEVWCbATRFBT9w.text: Finally made it here for sushi -  I've been putting it off  as I'm not a fan of sitting at the sushi bar  That said, the chefs didn't even make eye contact, so I was perfectly happy. Yeah, yeah, antisocial...  :)  They're docked a star from my perspective because there is no option to the bar/sushi bar area if you don't want hibachi and if someone is with you who doesn't like sushi, they are stuck eating off of the appetizer menu.  I always start with basic items when ordering sushi at a new restaurant - had salmon, tuna, shrimp and eel nigiri and a cucumber maki.  The fish was fresh, with decent texture, the cucumber was crispy, and overall Nakama might have taken over the number 2 sushi restaurant spot in my heart.

nbMSY61RBU9dvz7PXHp5oA.text: We had reservations for four people on a Saturday night at 8:00. We did not get seated until 9:00. In the bathroom I heard the hostess complaining about how backed up they were and that she wanted to tell the complaining guests "I don't know you, I don't care". This attitude aside, the rest of our service was really good. It was slow-going on getting drinks, but I could tell our server was really rushed. Hats off to the people at our "grill" who were going to the bar to buy drinks. It gets hectic at hibachi places, and they did a pretty good job for being as busy as they were. Our hibachi chef was awesome and adorable. He was really a lot of fun, and you could tell he knew what he was doing.  The drinks were reasonably priced, as was the menu. I think it was about $45.00 for me by myself with a hibachi meal and two Kettle One cocktails. The shrimp was good, and the steak was really tender. The fried rice was definitely not the best hibachi-fried rice I have ever had, but it hit the spot. I really liked their miso soup, it didn't have tofu, which made me happy!  I would love to go back and try the sushi, although I will probably avoid coming here during a peak hour, whether or not I have reservations. Definitely better than Benihana, although I have had better hibachi.

utDZM6t1a041loatC6hyOA.text: Friday May 15 my friend had reservations for 9:00PM for a surprise birthday dinner at Nakama. Because of Nakama's strict seating policy when it comes to reservations, she spoke directly to a manager, and requested that the guests be allowed to sit before the guest of honor arrived so that it would in fact be a "surprise". The manager agreed and assured her that there would be no problem granting that request.   The guests arrived at 8:30 PM and informed the host that we were all present for our 9 PM reservation. The host told us we would be called when it was available.   We were still waiting in the bar to be seated at 10PM. An hour after the guest of honor arrived, (so much for the surprise). When we were finally seated everyone ordered appetizers and drinks right away. It took 20 minutes to receive our drinks. And believe me, I'm not exaggerating for effect here; I was timing it on my watch. My appetizers arrived at about 10:30.    We placed our dinner orders shortly before the apps showed up, which would be around 10:25. The chef did not arrive to start cooking until 10:50.   I addressed this with the server who gave me excuses about the shortage of chefs and how they were backed up, but I noticed people who arrived after us, who were also seated before us (with comparable party numbers) were almost finished with their meals before our chef arrived.  The waiter clearly didn't understand that I wasn't interested in excuses and passed me onto a manager. The manager apologized and went to grab a chef for us. However when the meal was finally cooked and served it was 11:30. All after we were supposed to be seated at 9.   On of the couple's who was with us, never received an appetizer after waiting for 1.5 hours. The appetizer was Ahi Tuna, which requires NO cooking. The manager offered a free dinner, but by that time our friends were so disgusted that they left.   I have to say that we were one of the last tables to leave the seating area, which was after midnight. We spent way too much money on drinks while we were waiting to be seated and eat our dinner. No one at the table was compensated for the aggravation. One of the girls at the table is a newscaster for channel 4, and I would love to see her comment on the negative experience we had.   I strongly urge people who are interested in a hibachi style dining experience to seek other venues. If it is sushi you are interested in, try the Downtown Fish Market, Umi, or Yakoso.

Ty5tAo3oIDGlzweE5aWF8w.text: I really wish this place was great, but unfortunately, the decor does not make up for the mediocre sushi and the abhorrent clientele.  That place during happy hour reminds me of a Bosch painting, except for populated by yuppies instead of the naked damned.  The waitstaff is decent, but the hibachi chefs are kind of weak.  If you go on the weekend, you can have an awkward conversation about how loud you pee with the bathroom attendant.  I guess there's not a lot of small talk to be had.  I have had fun in this place, but I can have fun pretty much anywhere.  Oh, and if it is crowded, good luck hearing a word that anybody says.

2JM35PZ99g8kufh4GvNW5g.text: I went to Nakama on Saturday for my birthday. I had a party of 9 and told the hostess my friend was in traffic and would be late. She insisted they could not seat us until everyone in my party arrived which to me seemed to inconvenience them more because we were occupying the lobby and seemed to be in the way. Once seated, it took long to get everything. A long wait to order drinks, then receive our drinks, then long to take our order. My reservation was for 8 and by 8:45 we hadn't even put our food order in. I ordered a margarita and 30min later I still hadn't received it so my friend complained to the manager who was walking around. He was very apologetic and explained our waitress was actually a hostess and he bought me the margarita. That definitely saved the night and I am thankful for his generosity. The food is good, your basic hibachi food. I didn't order sushi but my friends seemed to enjoy it.

ItWkEkIRNwsrTR4GUh3JUg.text: OK so June 17,2016 I went on a date with my girlfriend.  She chose this restaurant she never been there before.  So we get there and we have my vehicle valet parking.  We eat then we get the check not only did the server try to over charge for my meal heal sat in my face and told me that I asked for my meal to be separately rang up.  Why would I do that an it would cost more?  But any who then we go out to get my vehicle and it takes about ten minutes for him to come back with it. Now today I get a parking ticket in the mail talking about a parking violation!  But how I ask?  I don't know but guess who won't be eating here ever again.

HN9JMAClrO6GjLCps-GqOA.text: Went with a group and sat at the sushi bar. Service was not so good. One person's meal was served after the other three of us had several orders of sushi. We ordered two orders of sashimi and only one was on the platter. Quality of sushi ok. One was stringy. Valet returned car keys because they were going to leave early.

8w3LZ36Hyx8yx5aF8dfH-Q.text: Owners have very bad attitudes and customer service skills. Waitress was lazy and didnt look like she wanted to be there. Our food was overcooked . I wouldn't recommend eating here when they're better Asian cuisine and other restaurants on East Carson.

-zQLkomMs-UY9p1PxVzEAw.text: No! Just no on the hibachi. The sushi was ok but overshadowed by the horrible experience in the back at the hibachi area that we couldn't really enjoy it. Overpriced, badly cooked...yep, bad hibachi shrimp. Way overdone and chewy. The chicken as well. The "soup" was made from a buillion cube.the salad was a nasty glob of something on some shitty lettuce. And our server was nice and attentive but too busy because they were understaffed. Finally, our hibachi "chef" said not a word nor did he smile. I think maybe he's there against his will. All this for $250! No thanks. Steer clear. They should be out of business soon and something decent in that nice location.

UAQMVeBgcxrcyVyceSTaSg.text: Note: for sushi bar. Did not go for Hibachi (because I've had enough of Benihana and it seemed really pricey). Wait was also nonexistent for sushi at the bar.   Another disclaimer: I'm used to California sushi restaurants & chains (Japanese friends would have MUCH higher standards) and I haven't had good sushi since I've moved out to DC.  Friend & I shared: Pittsburgh Penguins Roll (when in Pittsburgh...), Spicy Squid Salad, Salmon Ceviche (cannot find on online menu), and Philadelphia roll (because somehow my friend has NEVER had it?)  Everything was really good! I especially liked the spicy squid salad and the salmon ceviche- the latter had pretty thick pieces of salmon but was so nicely presented that I didn't really mind at all (the same cannot be said for everyone.)   Overall: good, solid Japanese restaurant. Would go again.

nUgxi4PnDKpzUSFcXdGxdQ.text: Nakama tries to be very trendy, but I have experienced much better sushi for a better price.  Still, the sushi is better than many people claim.  I had very good service here.  And there is some great people watching.  But we have much better choices for Japanese food in Pittsburgh.

tHYDc5380ZbscsVq_ninhQ.text: One of the best sushi places in Pittsburgh. Only problem is that it is usually very crowded and the noise is not well isolated, so sometimes it is hard to talk over dinner. Also, tables for sushi are too small and too close to each other. But food is outstanding, especially specialty rolls and fried rice at hibachi tables

PO4-wpcyjKc7jcnDRVOpAQ.text: I am a little sad to have had this experience with Nakama in the last times I've been here because it used to be my favorite sushi place in Pittsburgh. My last time here was yesterday,  the worst experience ever. I went there with a friend and we sat down in the high tables area, and the table was super dirty and STICKY! #Ew we informed the waitress about the situation and she cleaned it. The quality of the food that night was bad also, we had the steak hibachi and it arrived cold and tasted like it was there since yesterday. The food quality was really bad in the last times I've been here and I wanted to give Nakama one last shot. After this time, NEVER TO COME BACK AGAIN.  The service was never that great and now the food quality has gotten just as bad + coming to a dirty table = really disappointed

ZBM1zztcBJCsR_2pwKm0_g.text: The wait was way to long just to be seated, the service is mediocre and the prices are too high for sushi. Decided to go somewhere where I could actually be seated.

uHohNrgxkwHWZ0OU0NmhXQ.text: Food here has finally gotten to the level of the service. Fish used in the Sushi is of low quality and is no longer worthy of eating. Service at the bar in the daytime is very lacking.   The bartenders act like they are doing you a favor by waiting on you. Oh almost forgot to mention... The still have Oktoberfest beer on tap in mid December. The beer is from August. Throw it away and put a Xmas beer there. Or wait till may to do that...  Another case of the owners just milking the gravy of what they built. Can't blame them I guess. Place was really good 8 years ago when it had to be.  Update... 1/1/16  Had to meet a client there today. Black curly haired bartender acted like she was doing us a favor by giving us a menu.   SHE WAS RUDE AND IGNORANT!!! For zero reason. Just plain mean. If she is not an owner or related to them then she must have pictures of the owner in a compromising position. Otherwise who would want her in a service industry position.   She gave me a menu that looked like it was out in the rain for 3 days. Was really ignorant about it too. I just suggested we go somewhere much more worthy of our money so we left. But not before I apologized to her for being a bother by simply sitting down at the bar she was working.   Although I work on the south side and love sushi, I will never go back into this place. Zero management I guess. Sad...

YLKUq2oGLpkrkfcTHG1Vyw.text: This place was so delicious. I was nervous because it only had three stars but man was I in for a surprise. Great food, clean atmosphere, and very nice bartender! So happy my wife and I gave it a chance!

pJYQbyMLSlu0Lbd7jdpTiw.text: I am currently at my table and just couldn't wait to rave about my experience here!!! We came during happy hour and had excellent deals on drinks and apps! We got an array of sushi as well, my favorite being the Crunchy Philly.. and that's coming from someone who isn't much of a sushi eater!   Everyone was also very happy with their martinis and they have a wide range of selections to satisfy any craving! Our server, Marissa was so sweet and very attentive to us! Our drinks never went dry and she was more than excellent.   We all enjoyed our experience here immensely! Thanks Marissa!

zBRmb35vQrp_Qv6uYYnmaQ.text: I love me some sushi, and the dragon roll (sans cream cheese) was great, but im pretty sure it wasnt supposed to be in a soy wrap as our other roll was (salmon & spicy tuna, something). We also ordered sashimi which was great but sushi guy with the green eyes, why do you look at me like I'm stupid when I say "my miso soup is cold."  It was super busy, so sitting at the sushi bar with the door constantly swinging open and the freezing air flowing in and out was pretty annoying, and the hip hop on someones ipod was kinda random, but overall it was just ok.

0745KnS5JpJHGofs7hl8dA.text: Working on the Southside, I have been visiting Nakama 1-3 times per year since it opened. This place has definitely gone downhill. I probably would have given 4 stars when it first opened but not now. Food and service was not great at all. Probably won't go back unless I have to for some work-related function.

815mQgMiQbRYisV7tPp62Q.text: Sat at one of the tables by the window.... I had the cucumber salad, shrimp egg rolls and ahi tuna... All were very delicious! Nice portion of the cucumber salad and the egg rolls were so crispy and the sauce was so yummy!  I'm new to ahi tuna and it was just what I was expecting, I left very happy :) my boyfriend had the shrimp hibachi he cleared the whole plate and not to mention it's really nice you can order hibachi at one of the tables in the front. Our server was nice and she really made sure we had a great time! Can't wait to go back again

photos.caption: Photo of Nakama - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Egg rolls , ahi tuna and cucumber, dinner is served :)

N9a8e06UABH_PIpta1FCYQ.text: Our party of 7 went in for hibachi on a Friday night. We made reservations and only had to wait a couple of minutes for the table to be ready. Three of us were vegetarians and the waitress was nice enough to let us know that the soup had a meat based broth. Our chef was great and even prepared our vegetarian food before putting the meat on the grill. Overall great and delicious experience!

9rOvUgsnFxAaO3NBxTSE-w.text: If I had to describe Nakama in three words it would be "Overpriced, Loud, Boring". For a hibachi steak house, this place really doesn't seem to care about the whole, hibachi part. It basically is just watching someone cook food in front of you, there's no show, no flare, just a dude in a chefs hat frying your rice and leaving once you have your food. On top of that, for the price, the food is not even close to good enough to justify it, nor do you get enough of it. In all honesty if someone told me this place is only in business because of its location, I would believe them because the quality alone is not even close to enough to carry this place. I would not recommend going to this place, but I would recommend you check out Ichiban if you need your hibachi fix.

x8QVUqjaV8_vzgX6z2h3MA.text: I'm a celiac and the cook carelessly made my food with wheat and I was informed after I ate half my meal... NEVER come here with an allergy, the cooks apparently "don't read the tickets" according to the manager.  P.S. Bathroom looked like an atom bomb when off.

_2lZbG0AsxprroBxX2MV-A.text: I had a reservation at 7:00 pm. I wasn't seated until around 7:40. It also seemed as if they were short on cooks because our table sat for a significant amount of time before the cook showed up. Subsequently, we didn't eat until 8:45. I prefer Ichiban.

riGzOQe2X-3NEh7-6msBBQ.text: The very first place i ever got to try sushi at, and i ordered a few different rolls too. I liked all the ones i tried. The shrimp tempura was delicious too!

Bz_KEvFEyKL1QtbFe1BLtQ.text: This is my second time visiting the restaurant down on the Southside and I have to say that the food was fantastic as usual, but this visit this time around the service by our waitress(Haley) was mediocre. My friend ordered a wine(Pinot Noir) but she came back with a Pinot Grigio, which is a common mistake and not too much of a big deal. But when she was asked to take back the drink she got snippy with us. She also had out chef confused with what she has written down and our food was going to the wrong plate. The occasion was my friends birthday and when another one of her friends came by she didn't want to take his drink order. She completely messed up our payments and got snippy with us when we were confused. Our overall experience with Haley was terrible. The only reason why I tipped her 20% was because I am also a server and know the struggle. The food was delicious and yum yum sauce is great, which is why I still recommend this place and love coming here when in town.

photos.caption: Photo of Nakama - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

woqDPUzVJ0IsxR8kqDpNSg.text: We flew into Pittsburgh for two days for a penguins playoff game...I don't know why this place has three stars...we were in Pittsburgh for two nights and ended up here for dinner after bar hopping all day.  We got some appetizers and I had teriyaki chicken skewers and chicken with rice.  Drinks were extra strong, but not too much to the point of not being drinkable, just generously poured.   We had a great time here and would absolutely return on our next trip.

dfRsnRQkth3gdpIDtBlWiQ.text: I've had a lot is sushi in my life. Being thai and Laotian, I've eaten a lot of raw "protein" dishes. Sushi was Not fishy at all here. Pretty impressed with that. Fishy ness is not necessarily a bad thing (in asian cuisine that is) but when u can't even smell it here...it says something.

tJJgmqlKGgkITywLV_ii4Q.text: My mom has a visual disability and was dining at Nakama. She was having a difficult time seeing in the restaurant, and then the chef lit the grill on fire in front of her, which startled her into spilling soup all over herself and the floor. It's pretty standard customer service to provide assistance in cleaning up spills, but nobody from Nakama offered to help with cleanup. When they're charging $69.99 for a strip steak, there's no excuse for the incredibly poor customer service that my mom experienced.

QnscX4G5nbg8Ww9_sQO1Iw.text: The events that took place yesterday afternoon at Nakama leave me ultimatley confused and extremely saddened. I no longer live in Pittsburgh, but it is still the place I consider home. What do you do when you come home to visit? You visit loved ones, celebrate birthdays, weddings, graduations, and you eat all of your favorite spots! I joked with friends, "I CAN'T WAIT TO GO TO NAKAMA"! Well never shall I step foot in that place again. I have celebrated birthdays, friends birthdays, celebrations, heck my family even took my GRANDMA there for her 91st birthday this past December! I've have birthday celebrations there with over 50 people! Long story short over the course of goodness 5+ years I have been a patron of Nakama. For Pittsburgh, this once was a place that was sort of a staple for the community. You take your friends from out of town there...It was simply thee place to meet a friend for a quick drink and appetizer, or for me a sports girl, even dine at the window and watch a game or two...NOT ANYMORE! Frankly once management changed and the playing cards came off the ceiling the service and FOOD was never the same! I'm not making this up, but I have seriously gotten sick several times, yet my simple behind would still go back because "its Nakama", "it's my FAV"! Even yesterday before we left SkyBar a friend reminded me, "Girl last time you went there before you moved to NYC, you got sick!" I was like OMG, you're right! Yet me and 7 other friends happily marched down to Nakama because we wanted to do an impromptu following of tradition a CELEBRATE A BIRTHDAY, quickly at the bar. We sat down ordered food and drinks, everything was fine... A manager comes over and says to my friend whose birthday it was... (of course he ruined her bday) you need to cover up we have a strict dress code. Now mind you my friend next to me had the same sheer sleeveless version over her bikini...My friend who the manager chose to point out, her cover up was long sleeve, floor length.. and she had on shorts. Why he chose to single out one girl and not the other puzzling if you catch my drift. Mind you..... our other friend had another cover up on who in my opinion was more scandalous than both of those put together! Anywho, we say okay, cool, she holds her cover closed and he walks away. By this time all drink and dinner orders had been placed and we saw another friend who thought we were still at SkyBar walk past the Nakama window, so my friend who had just been yelled at runs out to get her. Our friend who was just arriving has on a bikini top but BEFORE WALKING INTO NAKAMA SHE PUTS ON A SHIRT! My birthday friend comes in and sits down and the manager storms back over and begins yelling. He said something like I told you, you cant wear that in here and you will be asked to leave... Some people's food had actually begin to come out, so they are like huh?! We are eating?! He gets louder and louder... we were like look... she has buttons it's buttoned... Mind you we are at the bar...Seated! No one can really even tell what the heck you have on! We weren't in the dining room we were at the bar! And to top it off, it wasn't even busy! Other patrons were watching and making comments, after the discussion with the manager escalated because he was NOT being reasonable -he then told us to get out!? WHAT?!HUH?! I guess the customer isn't always right... They just lost hundreds of dollars over a bathing suit cover up (see picture) Other patrons were disgusted actually telling us sorry, that was rude and disgusting. I woke up this morning to a long post from a women saying how what she witnessed how it was degrading and uncalled for. Here's the best part my friend sat there to finish her water and the manager called the police! The Pittsburgh Police !They spoke2 the manager inside and then came out to speak to us and frankly, the cops thought it was a joke also. They said they aren't they dress code police they are the real police. This manager took time out of the cops day when they could have actually been needed elsewhere to whine about some swimsuit coverups! What a joke. I miss the old Nakama not this stuck up, stuffy one, with lying managers and clearly some personal problem with race... He clearly singled out my black friend and said nothing to my white friend and for what?!Why?! We were just coming there to do what we always do year after year celebrate a birthday! I had a flight back to NYC that night but I was willing to risk missing my flight just to eat a little bit of Nakama. Due to a flight change I ended up not even having time to eat because I missed my dinner opportunity due to an incompetent managers stupidity. Dear Nakama, my old friend who is fake and clearly has changed, you won't get another cent from me and all of my family and friends! Just how a random strangers post was able to make it to me on Facebook only hours later, she won't be returning nor will her friends! PGH is small so we will all continue to talk!

photos.caption: Photo of Nakama - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Oh okay?!

6BRHmFDGBWIiDaeBosQG6w.text: This place is the worst. The food isn't good and it's super pretentious. Plus there's that whole racist and sexist dress code policy (see other recent reviews). I haven't been in years, but I will certainly NEVER go again.

C3PY-3MIEnVPUhnQv7DMWQ.text: $60 for takeout and I've had better food from the #1 ChinaHouse. Portion sizes were stingy and a joke for the price - It's like there was a nationwide shortage of shrimp. $4 for mushroom flambe that consisted of 8 sliced up pieces(total rip off). Tastes were bland and non-existent - onion soup tasted like Swanson beef broth straight out of the can. Things were left out of the order no soy sauce for the California roll, no chopsticks, and total lack of service. I would expect more from a so-called 5 star Japanese Steakhouse. I work hard for my money and will never waste it again on this hype. Save your time and money and just go to Ichiban.

i_m7mmtzQLqaoRwhTumCwg.text: Great restaurant!The food was perfect.The cook was funny,friendly,told us funny stories while his cooking! Delicious!

ogELru3sMCqFfREQs2mp-A.text: Decent Hibachi food. Solid 3 stars.  My boyfriend and I came to Katama for a Hibachi dinner on a Wednesday night. We have high expectations when it comes to Hibachi because our taste buds have been acquired to meet the Hibachi standards of Nakato in Atlanta, however I will TRY my best to give an unbiased opinion.  To start off, Nakama was fairly empty for a Hibachi restaurant. We were seated immediately after arriving and ordered drinks. I orders the Slush Puppie which I thought would be a frozen mixed drink but instead it was not frozen at all and tasted like a melted Blue Raspberry Slushie from Quick Trip. For entrees, I ordered the Teryaki  chicken and my boyfriend ordered the Shrimp and Chicken. We noticed that the prices were on the more expensive side ranging from $18-40 with an additional charge of $3.75 for fries rice.  Our Hibachi chef came out moments later looking a bit unenthused and seemed to be new to the Hibachi grill. I sat patiently waiting for the big fire opening at the beginning of every Hibachi experience but this time it didn't happen. Our chef started right on the appetizers! I ordered the Shrimp appetizer which was pretty standard, and my boyfriend opted for the mushroom appetizer which was yummy. Next up came the vegetables lacking in flavor.. I ended up having to sprinkle my veggies with soy sauce for taste. The fried rice tasted a little off to me as well, as if it were cooked with margarine instead of the traditional Hibachi seasoned butter. Our entrees were decent but well portioned with enough to take home for left overs.   Overall, their Hibachi recipes lack in flavor and seasoning. The prices are comparable to Benihana's however the portion sizes provide enough for left overs.

iWFbuWKaqJpvx5Dw6T8q8A.text: Not highly suggested. Solid restaurant, cool atmosphere, and above average food. The lighting is insanely dark (at later hours); which makes reading hard and eye contact impossible. I have one absolute complaint: the splitting meal charge. If you and a friend split a meal, they charge $10. I think that it is all together an unnecessary charge; and even if the charge is somewhat of a requirement, ten dollars is too much. There ain't nothing wrong with some ladies wanting to split a hibachi meal.  BUT EDDY IS THE REAL OG. He works hibachi and he's an angel. That's all.

7tF4zqOwq1rmCupi2GSvDg.text: This is your typical hibachi place.  The Spider roll was a lot of imitation crab meat, but it was very nicely rolled and presented well. It was a slightly crunchy soft shell crab.  We shared a triple combo and the chef was confused? / annoyed? that we were sharing...but we were glad we did in the end...between the two of us, we STILL had food left over.  Started us each out with a bowl of miso soup, and it had fried onions and mushrooms in it, which was different, and appreciated.  The salad was good with a yummy sauce and mixed greens, carrots and tomatoes. On the better side of the salads I've had like this.  Our combo had steak, shrimp, and chicken...and it was just... a TON of rice and a tonnn of veggies. It was delicious, but as usual it was on the saltier side. That is hibachi for you, though. Pretty good.  Our server didn't really put on a show. Not sure if he knew English that well. He did all the demos, but didn't interact with us too much as I've been used to in the past.

photos.caption: Photo of Nakama - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Spider roll

n4tO8JHXjHQJDhoeztIaVA.text: This used to be our favorite sushi & sashimi bar in Pittsburgh but it seems the quality & service are travelling down hill, or at least they were last night.  We went here for my birthday and were greeted by the hostess with a blank stare.  She didn't say anything...  Nothing...  So I said, 'Hi, we'd like a teppanyaki table', to which she responded with another blank stare.  Then I said 'Hibachi...' and she woke up and said, 'That'll be at least 15-20 minutes or so...' and then went back to her blank stare.  Nothing like, 'Would you like to grab seats at the bar? Start your meal off with a drink? How about a sushi roll while you wait...' nothing...  So I said, 'Ok, we'll wait...' and seated ourselves at the sushi bar.  It took at least 5 minutes for the actual waitress to appear and it seemed like it was a chore for her to get us a couple glasses of water.  She didn't offer any help picking out rolls or sushi so we were on our own.  We settled on a 'Steeler Roll' for $14.  Looking around at the closest hibachi table to us, I could see 6 people seated and 2 empty seats.  I figured they were waiting for someone- turned out they weren't.  I also assumed that maybe they had ordered already- they hadn't.  Had they ordered drinks already maybe- Nope...  It was obvious that the hostess just wanted to be ignorant and make us wait for another table.  Ok, fine.  She doesn't get tipped anyway.  So our roll arrives and we start in on it.  It tastes pretty good but the eel that we so love is being lost in the quantity of rice surrounding it.  It even had trouble staying together.  Then the hostess comes over and says 'Are you ready...?' to which I look at her, then at the roll, and say, 'We'll need a few minutes...'  On to the teppanyaki table...  The restaurant was super loud because I think there was an 'End of the Season Pittsburgh Steeler party' in the back room and they were making all kinds of commotion so I can't fault the waiter on how hard it was for all of us to hear him.  Oh, by the way- our table was only half full when they started service.  There was my wife & I and another couple.  Maybe they were trying to get us in & out quickly, I don't know...  Our waiter started to take our orders and I heard him offer the couple next to us, 'Would you like to upgrade your white rice for fried for an additional charge?' and they both said no.  Looking in the menu, I see that a side of fried rice without any purchase is $3.29 so when it came time for us to order, he offered the same thing and I asked him how much the 'upcharge' was.  $3.29 was his response.  Why wouldn't he just ask if we'd like an additional side of fried rice for $3.29 instead of making it sound like you were getting a better deal by declining the white rice in favor of fried for $3.29???  Stuff like this really bothers me so I told him, 'I would like fried rice but I also want the steamed rice I'm already paying for...' to which he says, 'Fine with me man, I don't care how much rice I bring out...'  Nice customer service...  Anyway, we ended up with the only American teppanyaki chef in the entire place, and he was just getting over bronchitis or something because he barely spoke and when he did, it was in a very low tone.  Don't get me wrong- he was a very nice guy...  My wife had ordered the Bob's Triple Combo (Strip steak, Chicken & Shrimp) and I ordered the Chef's Choice (Strip steak & Chicken).  They were both delicious and aside from the service issues, we had a very nice meal.    We both agreed though- next time we're going out for sushi- we're going to Sake at South Side Works.  The chefs are much friendlier, the fish is fresher and the prices are much more reasonable (Half price on Sunday's & Monday's)

photos.caption: Photo of Nakama - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

EBcvbEesNvmvlzgYJlK1Ag.text: I will never go back to this damn nakama again. I made reservation on open table. When we arrived none of the hosts greeted us they were just standing and talking on the podium. I finally told them I had reservations and they escorted us to a table with a group. We didn't want to sit with a group we just wanted a table for two. So we ask if we could switch the seats they were offering us and they did. When the waiter arrived it was apparent he had an attitude. He asked us what we wanted to drink and was there anything else we wanted. We weren't given any menus I asked for a menu and he only brought us one menu and there was two of eating. After noticing his rude and annoying attitude wasn't going away, we decided to just get up and leave without even ordering. This nakama has the worst service.

YHw531MaRH0JIQkm1cXvxA.text: So I'm in town working and went and sat at the bar to get a quick dinner before a show.  They had a dry Riesling on the menu and I confirmed with the waitress that it wasn't sweet.  So I get it that this is a strip of tattoo parlors, vape stores and college bars, but there are also quite a few great restaurants hidden around the area.  So, I was a littel surprised when my wine was beyond syrupy.  Then I ordered a specialty roll.  Honestly, I ordered a cooked tempura sushi with avocado.  It came drowned in about three different sauces.  It wasn't compelling. On the positive side, service was fast and friendly. The place was crowded and people seemed to be having a great night. I won't be going back.

tQvLwKNeSNx55tban-cSzw.text: I came here last weekend and had a great meal. We sat at the sushi bar and the bartender (I can't remember her name but she was pregnant) was absolutely fantastic. She was super quick and we had wanted mules but she didn't have anymore cups. As soon as one turned up she brought us mules .... on the house! So kind! We enjoyed a lobster role and some tuna sashimi which was to die for. So fresh and delicious. I had such a great night, my boyfriend wanted to come back the following night so it was a winner in my bo

iS0W9nAR3n2OluEAYV0AzA.text: My husband and I went here today to celebrate our anniversary, we were there in the afternoon because of our work schedules. We had an amazing time!! Even though it was still "lunch time " they fired up the hibachi table for just the two of us! Luke was our chef, and he was awesome!! We had a blast, and we'll definitely be back!! Also, the prices for the lunch menu were discounted, win win in my book!!

MdpJD1v50fNKfZ5OUAwFcg.text: Nakama might be a little pricy, but it's well worth the cost. I recommend incorporating the seared Ahi tuna into your selection. It melts in your mouth! The atmosphere is lively, but still conducive to conversation.  The Hanalei Roll, a tempura flash fried sushi roll, is my very favorite sushi roll.   The cocktails are tasty and extremely strong. The Slush Puppie Martini is my favorite!

photos.caption: Photo of Nakama - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Hanalei Roll and Hawaiian Style Maki

xIWxty19uQo8HesyMGshFw.text: While this is still primarily a Japanese hibachi, it is clearly better than the numerous chains that have been popping up everywhere. The major difference being the quality of the ingredients and cooks. My steak and seafood is always cooked perfectly to temperature, which can be spotty at some of the competitors. Also, I would rate the sushi here among the best in Pittsburgh. Also you can get some menu items you just don't find elsewhere. I particularly like the Diablo preparation with a spicy sauce and soba noodles.   The one knock would be the showmanship can be pretty hit or miss here depending who you get and there is really no innovation. A pretty standard show.

photos.caption: Photo of Nakama - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Nakama Maki
Photo of Nakama - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

EeY58EERsUnj4zXxjVQz1Q.text: We visited for lunch the other day and we were quite satisfied. Our server was super friendly and prompt. My husband and I are what I like to call fake-sushi fans, so we got a California Roll and a Spicy California Roll cuz we were feeling craaaazy that day. We also ordered the coconut shrimp. Everything came out in a reasonable amount of time, although the shrimp came out a couple minutes AFTER our sushi, and I would have preferred it before.  The sushi was well prepared and very tasty. The rolls stuck together just right and had good flavors. The sauce on the spicy rolls had just the right amount of heat. I know, there's not much to a California roll, but what can I say? We're sushi wimps. The coconut shrimp was nearly on par with Red Lobster's coconut shrimp (which are the best coconut shrimp out there) but a teensy bit dry. This was remedied by the yummy, spicy sauce on the side (strangely reminiscent of the sweet chili sauce McDonald's had out during the Olympics...)  All in all the service was great and we enjoyed our food, so we'll be back. The lunch hibachi prices are very reasonable so we hope to try that next time.

YjSeThElorWkZRYy21JBfA.text: If you are going to attempt to dine here on the weekend, make a reservation. I recommend Luke as your chef. He is very entertaining and his food is the best. I have never had a bad experience here with food or service. My girls, who are 9 and 8, are big fans of Nakama.

jY4coFzRCT2VOjxbYJ58AQ.text: This is a god-awful excuse for a restaurant.  The actual serving of food is last on its list of priorities, which run something like this: 1) Having heavily-made-up waitresses treat diners rudely. 2) Functioning as a place for bald-headed men to drink. 3) Using "valet parking" to totally tie up the intersection of 17th and Carson. 4) Being a mediocre-to-poor Americanized "Japanese" restaurant.  I had sushi the only time I came here (probably about three years ago).  It was really bad.  Cold, rubbery rice that not only didn't have any rice vinegar in it, but wasn't properly cooked.  Rolls looked like they had been created in a fit of pique by a drunken marmot or other mammal lacking opposable thumbs.  And the fish, while not being actively spoiled, was not notable for its freshness either.  If you want hibachi, try Yokoso.  If you want excellent, authentic sushi, try Chaya in Squirrel Hill.  If you want pretty decent, cheap sushi, try Oishii Bento in Oakland.  But for the love of god, don't come here for any reason.

bTBzOgAJrimi1OIyi3-NJw.text: 5 people. No booze. $200. Was the food remarkable? No. Was it acceptable? Yes. Was it difficult to see in the low-light ambiance? Yes. Are there alternatives? Certainly. Do I think this place is a bit over rated? Sorta, kinda, yes.

FLoeNSvNXUfgAjVQcs7uGw.text: It's interesting that one of the most crowded restaurants in the South Side (possibly, all of Pittsburgh?) has such bad ratings on Yelp. I think Yelpers have it right in the case. Nakama totally did not live up to the hype for me. I had the hibachi and it was just mediocre. The chef / entertainer wasn't even that good - no cool tricks and he didn't even try throwing food in my mouth. The place was so loud that there is no way you can have a decent conversation if you come with a group of people. And, I swear they celebrated 10 birthdays during the hour we were dining there. They have this irritating gong that they bring out. You can't hear the guy next to you, but you will hear every birthday dinner that night.   A bunch of my co-workers like Nakama's sushi bar, so when I get a chance to try it, I'll update my review. Until then, I'm not quickly planning my next Nakama outing.

wrq_pn3l4GrpD570lZfPHg.text: I ate at Nakama for the first time last night, sat at the sushi bar with two friends, ordered a ton of food, and an expensive bottle of sake (which was over priced and soso in quality). Despite the money we dropped, the service was horrible, simply put; unprofessional, rude, and snotty.  Now, this place has nothing to be uppity about: THEY DO NOT EVEN UNDERSTAND WHAT SUSHI IS. It was Americanized to the extreme, the menu was embarrassing, as with the wine and sake list. The sashimi was so poorly cut you could barley chew on it, the maki was not tightly rolled. And the fish... oh the fish, no flavor.  The hipster crowd should of tipped me off, this is place for people who do not know anything about dining, and probably only eat sushi because they think it's the cool thing to do. The crowd was nothing but meat heads and trashy looking girls, the music selections we're bottom of the barrel, and the blaring sports tv's would ruin anyones dinner who cares.

xVkwl2RYRegv1le_2ltHPw.text: I'm a big fan of hibachi-style cooking, and my old place on the South Side was right down the street from Nakama, so I was excited to try it when I still lived there.  Once was enough, I'll never go back there again.  The food was pretty terrible through and through.  The meat didn't taste very fresh, the soup and salad were both forgettable, and the fried rice was AWFUL.  I can't understand why this place is so popular, my best guess is that some people consider it a "classy", "cultured" destination to get drunk at.  There are plenty of those types of places on the South Side already, and I'd venture a guess that even the bars serve better food.

bAbT07FacrFn_NVUyr-RuQ.text: DISCLAIMER: I've only ever tried the sushi. I have no clue about the hibatchi bar.  I was delighted to see that I'm not the only one who finds this place to be completely overrated and overpriced. The sushi was your average run of the mill raw fish. Nothing special about the freshness or the imaginitivity of the rolls. That is, except for the price. I couldn't believe that a meal for such average sushi cost as much as it did.   If you're looking for some decent raw fish to feed your sushi craving, try Chaya in Squirrel Hill instead. You won't regret it.

A_nZR4gqv-T5mlXBlf8LZg.text: I went there with my son because he really wanted to go.  He loves sushi and is always excited about flying food, so what better place to go, right?  And it's always packed, which means it must be good, right?   Overall I'd say wrong.  The sushi was about the same quality that I get at Giant Eagle.  You know the kind... "I'm really jonesin for some sushi, but I guess I'll take the old salmon stuck on top of crunchy cold rice because I'm too lazy to put my ass in the car and drive to Sushi Kim or some other real sushi bar."  The hibachi: Quality level on par with Benihana.  Enough said.  It reminds me of what a chef friend of mine said about the Spaghetti warehouse one day: "Fancy Ragu".  The hibachi was fancy canned chop suey.  Oh, and the price.  One adult and one 14 year old lunch (2 small plates of sushi and 2 hibachi lunches) $80.00.  Someone hand me the Astroglide.  Quick.  I've been sampling these kinds of establishments on both coasts for the past 15 years, from Vancouver BC to San Diego, from Miami to Boston.  For what they charge, the quality should be much better and the staff should TRY to smile once in a while.  Sorry, honey, but tight skirt and 17 layers of makeup can't hide a mean heart.  Here ends the rant prescribed by this reviewer for this restaurant.

h22Z9SgzTgdDIAiGVaobNA.text: I'm really at a loss for what to say. Nakama has long been one of my favorite restaurants. This has been a favorite destination for birthdays and other special occasions. I went here for lunch on my wedding day! So when I moved recently, it's been a quest to get back there again. And then today happened...      I went today, expecting a pleasant and entertaining experience. Unfortunately, I didn't get what I was expecting. I went there, expecting the full knife-tossing, food-flaming experience. Instead, I got a cook who cooked out food with his head down, barely daring to even speak with us. Half of the table's food was finished cooking before he even started the other half, leaving my friends to make the decision to eat before us or wait till their food was cold. I kept waiting for him to set our meal aflame. It's my absolute favorite thing about hibachi restaurants. But it never happened. He finished cooking in silence, cleaned the cooktop, and left.      Now, I don't want to be entirely negative. The food WAS as delicious as I expected. Out waitress was very friendly and attentive. When one friend ordered the Nakama Panda (drink) and they were out of panda mugs, she provided us with a Lucky Cat mug instead.      This experience has left a bad taste in my mouth, but I sincerely hope and expect it to be better next time I go back. And I will. One less-than-expected trip will not spoil this fantastic restaurant for me!

iP1GdH9PrFte0KBqwYzfJQ.text: Today was my first experience at Nakama. I walked in with a group of 30 - 35 people and asked to be sat at the sushi bar. I was disappointed with the hostess when she told me  the sushi bar does not have that many seats. I suspected she was lying to me because at least two of the members of my group were black. So i asked if they could accommodate two, me and my piece. They happily said yes and informed us it was all self seating. I was genuinely surprised by the lack of Asian servers. Most of the servers were white. When the server came of i snidely requested a glass of their most expensive champagne, only to throw a hissy fit when I found out the brand was not one I enjoyed. I honestly had no idea of the names this was all in an attempt to seem pretentious and impress my piece I was with. After I got done humiliating the server I asked her for "just a water, with extra lemons on the side". I also asked for some obscure sweetener I knew they did not have. I rolled my eyes and said sweet n low will do. The sushi menu was archaic. There were no pictures of anything. It didn't help that the sushi bar has all the raw  fish and everything they use in their rolls in a glass case right in front of you at the bar. I was very upset when i couldn't find totinos pizza rolls on the menu, so I went with a crunchy Philly roll. I had no idea what to expect because as I said, there were no pictures. The sushi chef handed me my food directly as to intimidate me. I took it without flinching. The ho i was with seemed very pleased with her order. I on the other hand immediately told the server that wasn't what I ordered. I asked her what was in it and she began to list the ingredients, including uncooked salmon. I then began listing a number of diseases and sickness' you can obtain from eating raw sea food. I demanded she take it back and just get me a side of fries. Go figure, they didn't have french fries. So I ordered a well done filet and asked for ketchup, which they also didn't have. I explained to her that the Heinz ketchup factory was right across the bridge I was completely baffles as to how they did not have ketchup. Nevertheless, my steak was quite good and my partner enjoyed her meal so much that I scored so hard later that night, after 4 hours of heavy drinking followed by 10 minutes of me insisting to my piece I was fine to drive home. Overall Nakama was a great experience and I tipped my server $40,000.

gi-AV-8Jtz65EISriWeV3A.text: Better than Bennihanna and Shogun. A little more expensive but less filler and more protein. The Filet & Shrimp combo was perfect. Our server Rae was prompt and very mindful. 4 1/2 stars

lNYSJo6bZDt_wo77hEHt6Q.text: Found this place after the wait was too long at Fathead's down the street. It was crowded so we were offered a seat at the sushi bar and handed menu's but then found room at the regular bar and those menu's were higher priced! Ridiculous.  It was crowded and loud, why the dance music at sushi place?   The food was OK, the shrimp was a solid B, the strip steak was B+ but everything else was just average. The Japanese soup which is usually chicken based was mushroom based, yuck.  The small salad was trenched in too much dressing. The rice was decent, the sauce on the meals was just average. The check arrives with a higher price than the menu's. Turns out fried rice was $3.29 more than white, it would have been nice if the server told us ahead of time! Dinner and a Sapporo beer was $30 for one. Not a good value.

imMxCj6HKBm2v9VPpHg3fw.text: My sister & I went to the sushi bar on a Sunday afternoon and I was quite pleased. The chefs at the bar were very friendly and chatty (though I'm sure that had something to do with how empty the place was), and we got a ton of sushi for under $40. My sister got the spider rolls and I ended up stealing a few because they were so tasty. I live in Chicago, and the prices were pretty comparable to cheaper sushi there, so it was a great deal. My sister keeps saying we have to go back over the holidays, and I definitely agree!  EDIT: So we went back on Saturday and this time shared the maki platter, some Spider rolls, and the Hanalei rolls.  The hanalei rolls were by far the best sushi I have ever had. I am still having dreams about them.  That's all.

3JEO57tTVxIPGwH4V1bjgQ.text: I find the sushi rolls to be quite good contrary to several reviewers here, though I usually put most of my efforts toward hibachi.  My favorite hibachi meal is the kobe beef.  It's pricey, but the taste is a significant experience for me because I love steak.  Note, I am getting rolls and not nigiri or sashimi (go to Umi for that!).    I have been disappointed often times with the "performance" of the chef.  From an entertainment perspective, I've seen better, but the most important aspect is the food and I've always had it well prepared.    The drinks are well mixed in my experience.  I even ordered the one with the glowing ice cube once, which was great, if only for the ice cube and ensuing ridicule.  They offer a limited wine selection, but there are 1 or 2 decent options by the glass.  The place is definitely packed all the time, which either makes for good people watching or is sure to annoy you -- it depends what kind of person you are.  I happen to enjoy the crowd.  The bathroom attendant is a bit much though.  Yeah, it's pricey, but you get a lot of food.  Most times everyone I'm with ends up taking some for the road.

b3z_wN-D-sn3omSw4TnwOw.text: The speed of the service seems to be really hit or miss but the quality is good. Both hibachi and sushi are good.

rBKDNnBZjrFLv078Db2kmg.text: I have been to Nakama, many many times.  I usually just get sushi or maki.  You cant complain about this aspect of Nakama.  They always have good, fresh, tasty rolls.   It isn't the cheapest, but how cheap to you want sushi grade fish? They are good size portions too, so its not like your paying all for the presentation.  They move a lot of fish here, so it's unlikely you will get subpar seafood. The Dragon roll is awesome and I usually get the Caterpillar as well.  both nice sized rolls.  They do have hibachi in the back  but I've never tried that.

yHCvvreXhMQNCvGDaZvMcg.text: Good hibachi for Pitt.  Good tasty food, large portions and trendy environment.  I would recommended for group dinners, business travel dinners and Happy Hour.  Enjoy!

mEj3udzOv5SJBpXlciGiXA.text: The food is great if you are there for food and if it was still 2005.  The sushi is sub-par and on more than one occasion I've left their feeling a bit ill from it.   As another reviewer wrote, "Nakama has turned into a singles scene. "  I don't understand this phenomenon either as if you are there for more than 5 minutes you cannot go anywhere else without smelling like the inside of that place. You also have to wash your clothes twice to get it out, it's almost worse than cigarette smoke.

W7qYqH1NGVoe5LkN5u_40Q.text: Review for Bar/Scene Only:  My mom says my crackface cousin (she doesn't call him that) raves about this place.  My random childhood friend's boss told me I should come here to meet interesting people.    I went for drinky times.  I brought a City Paper with me, as I was alone and needed some entertainment.  I sat at the bar for about 20 minutes, watching everyone around me get served.  Two large, bald headed gentlemen sidled up and were taken care of immediately by the bartender.  Still nothing in front of me.    Eventually I was asked "Are you OK?" at which point I requested a drink list.  Now, I don't really go in for too much mixed alcohol or sweet stuff, so I ended up just ordering a Pearl (cold-unfiltered) sake.  I'm not sure what people see in this place.  I mean, the bar scene is almost all large and/or old(er) people who usually happen to be bald if they possess a scrotum.  I mean, that's fine, that's cool.  Just not what I consider a "happening scene".    Also, my bartender made me taste the sake before giving it to me.  I thinke maybe he thought I didn't know what I was ordering.  To be fair, I was the only one in the whole bar drinking sake, so maybe they don't sell that much of it.  The food may be tasty, but I was warned that it would "give me the poops".  Can't verify that though.    Has anyone else noted the playing cards stuck to the ceiling?  That's pretty cool.  I also like the exposed pipes.  It's really not so bad from a design standpoint.  Just a Pittsburgh kind of place, I guess...
